definitions.definition: a person who invites guests to a meal, a party, etc. or who has people staying at their house

examples.text: Ian, our host, introduced us to the other guests.
Sonja stayed with an Argentine **host family**.

definitions.definition: a country, a city or an organization that holds and arranges a special event

examples.text: The college is **playing host** to a group of visiting German scientists.
The wonderful city of Melbourne is host to this event.
The host club is to be congratulated on its organization of the tournament.
The town is playing host to a film crew.

definitions.definition: a person who introduces a television or radio show, and talks to guests

examples.text: The event will be opened by television host Bill Punter.

definitions.definition: an animal or a plant on which another animal or plant lives and feeds
a large number of people or things

examples.text: Lavender oil can relieve a whole host of ailments.

definitions.definition: the main computer in a network that controls or supplies information to other computers that are connected to it

examples.text: transferring files from the host to your local computer

definitions.definition: the bread that is used in the Christian service of communion, after it has been blessed
to be a place where a particular plant, animal or feature is found

examples.text: Australia is host to some of the world's most dangerous animals.
The acre of garden is host to a splendid bank of rhododendrons.
The park is host to a beautiful ornamental lake.

wordOrigin: noun senses 1 to 4 and noun sense 6 Middle English: from Old French hoste, from Latin hospes, hospit- ‘host, guest’. noun sense 5 Middle English: from Old French ost, hoost, from Latin hostis ‘stranger, enemy’ (in medieval Latin ‘army’). noun sense 7 Middle English: from Old French hoiste, from Latin hostia ‘victim’.
